column2: john, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: My doctor prescribed Vicoprofen for chronic tension headaches about 2 years ago.  Last year, I started to have severe back pain in my upper back, C7 vertebrae area, and continued to take the Vicoprofen. The MRI showed disc dehydration in that area, and I also had 2 prior injuries to that area in past years.  Since physical therapy and trigger point injections provided little if any relief, my doctor increased my dosage to 3 times per day.  I have been able to work, as I stand on my feel all day, and feel that the Vicoprofen has made the pain much more manageable. I have a sensitive stomach, and have tolerated this medicine quite well.  I also tried a nerve pain medicine called Neurontin which did nothing for may pain, and I tried Baclofen, an muscle relaxant.  Neither provided much help.  I cannot take muscle relaxers as they knock me out, so this Vicoprofen has been a real "life saver" for me because I get pain refief without feeling very drowsy.  Most of the specialists I saw didn't even realize that they make a Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen combination, and I am thankful to my Primary Care Doctor for his knowledge of it and greatful that it has helped me so much.

column2: BusyBee, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Vicoprofen is a lifesaver for some.  My guess is that most of the people who say it isn't as strong are used to hydro/APAP products.  Because APAP potentiates the effects of hydrocodone, it will seem a little stronger in equipotent doses.  That being said, some people (like myself) have never been helped by APAP, it simply does nothing for my pain.  Ibuprofen, on the other hand, is very helpful.  The effects of vicoprofen also last a bit longer than other formulations, therefore you can go longer between doses.  Good luck to everyone.

CeeCee, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Multiple tooth extractions, 18 in all over three trips.Most people don't know the strength of vicoprofen, I found that it is 7.5mg hydrocodone and 200 mg of Ibprofen. This medication greatly reduced pain in a short amount of time when taken on an empty stomach. Did not do much for inflammation so I took an additional 200mg Ibprofen. Only needed to take two doses daily. Remember effectiveness also has to do with your weight, tolerance to narcotics and nsaids in addition to how much food and type of food you eat.

I had fallen and suffered from a Lumbar Sprain and underwent physical therapy, and my doctor had put me on Hydrocodone accompanied with Tylenol, the dosage was 10mg/325mg, they made me deathly ill, so my doctor prescribed the Vicoprofen(vicodon and ibuprofen) 7.5/200mg and what a relief, the pills do not make me sick and it actually helps the pain and swelling. I would recommend this particular medicine to anyone who has a reaction to Hydrocodone and Acetametaphine.

column2: EMTERT27PA, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I asked my md to switch me to it from lorcet or norco.  I have had to over time, take a GREAT deal of narcotic meds with tylenol in it.  We first went from lortab/lorcet to norco to help it out.  Then I found Vicoprofen.  It makes just much more good sense to me to save the liver the damage for sure if you have to take it in large amounts on a regular basis over an exntended period of time.  Plus, the ibuprofen in it has very very good anti-inflam. properties in it too.......so it makes much more sense for a pain killer in my opinion!  Wish I had found it sooner.  Once I get through with school, I will be prescribing it to my patients across the board over the other narcotics out there of the same strenght (7.5mg hydro).

I have TMJ disfuction, degrenerative disc disease, fibromagia, migranes. I was taken Norco 7.5/325. The Dr downgraded me to some Tylenol/codene pill that i found out I was allergic to & almost died in my sleep. They switched me to this which is much weaker then the Norco. Its ok nothing great.

column2: kimberly_lach37@, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have taken this medication, it was new to me, after taken regular Vicodin ES 750 mg. And it seems to me that it is not stronger.. (VICOPROFEN).. The doctor told me it was better cause it had Ibrophen, in it.. but is seems weak to me.. do they make another one stronger perhaps. please let me know. thanks KIMBERLY

column2: Alli, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My use of this particular medication provided relief from chronic pelvic pain associated with endometriosis and adenomyosis. The medication is very effective in treating my aches and throbbing type pain but did not have much effect on the sharp shooting pains I experienced periodically when sitting or bending. The side effects experienced were quite limited. It causes constipation which ultimately needs to be treated with some OTC type product to relieve it. The other was a feeling of light-headedness coupled with trouble holding attention on a given task or mental exercise. This product has, over time, created two issues for me. One is that of dependency and the other is of tolerance. I had a brief period of time when I had no medication. Within two days, I experienced severe muscle tightening, sinus drainage and an inability to sleep. The anxiety associated with the onset of these symptoms increased a feeling of what I'll call a "tuning fork" effect or "buzz" throughout my body. Not a good feeling whatsoever. The tolerance issue is that it now takes more medication to achieve the same level of pain relief. This is of great concern as the medication contains ibuprofen. Too much of this and other body functions become affected.Overall, the benefit outweighs the risks and side-effects for my situation.
